thinkers.name: Thomas H. Doctor
thinkers.context: Scholar of Buddhist Philosophy and Madhyamaka, specialist in AI and neuroscience, principal of Rangjung Institute, director of Center for the Study of Apparent Selves.

thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Groundbreaking biologist at Tufts University who developed the Cognitive Light Cone model of intelligence, pivotal collaborator in bridging Buddhist and AI concepts.

thinkers.name: Jay Garfield
thinkers.context: Professor at Yale working on dialogue between Buddhist classical philosophy and contemporary philosophy, facilitated Doctor's collaboration with AI scientists.

thinkers.name: Pete Hutch
thinkers.context: Professor of astrophysics at The Institute For Advanced Study in Princeton, head of interdisciplinary studies program, founded Earth-Life Science Institute.

thinkers.name: Olaf Vitkovski
thinkers.context: Linguist and AI scientist active in Artificial Life research, president of International Association for Artificial Life, core collaborator in Center for Study of Apparent Selves.

thinkers.name: Lisa Solomonova
thinkers.context: Cognitive scientist, phenomenologist, and philosopher at McGill University, expert on dreams and nightmares, bridges Buddhism and AI perspectives.

thinkers.name: Bill Dwane
thinkers.context: Former Google executive who headed core applications including Gmail in early 2000s, brings AI industry experience to Center for Study of Apparent Selves.

thinkers.name: Chigim
thinkers.context: Abbot of Shedeling Monastery in Kathmandu, lineage holder in Nyingma and Kagyu traditions, provides Buddhist perspective on intelligence and care in collaborative research.

thinkers.name: Clausida Mates
thinkers.context: Scholar of Buddhist Philosophy at HKU, director of Center of Buddhist Studies, 30-year colleague of Thomas Doctor.

thinkers.name: Daniel Golman
thinkers.context: Connected Doctor with MIT's Media Lab during networking efforts to find AI collaborators.

thinkers.name: Douglas Duckworth
thinkers.context: Faculty at Temple University who connected Doctor with Pete Hutch at Institute For Advanced Study.

concepts.name: Emptiness
concepts.context: Buddhist philosophical concept that all phenomena lack inherent, independent existence; central to Madhyamaka philosophy.

concepts.name: Anatta (Non-Self)
concepts.context: Buddhist doctrine that there is no permanent, singular, unchanging self; core teaching across Buddhist traditions.

concepts.name: Self
concepts.context: Concept of individual identity; central point of convergence and divergence between Buddhist philosophy and AI science.

concepts.name: Buddhist Philosophy
concepts.context: Teaching and philosophical system of Buddhism emphasizing dependent arising and the nature of suffering and liberation.

concepts.name: Madhyamaka philosophy
concepts.context: Buddhist philosophical school emphasizing emptiness and the absence of inherent existence in all phenomena.

concepts.name: Dependent Arising
concepts.context: Core Buddhist principle that all phenomena arise in dependence on multiple causes and conditions; key concept for AI-Buddhist dialogue.

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of suffering or unsatisfactoriness; first Noble Truth; central to understanding the Stress-Care-Intelligence model.

concepts.name: Buddha Nature
concepts.context: Buddhist teaching that all sentient beings possess inherent Buddha natureâ€”perfect capacity for awakening and enlightenment.

concepts.name: Omniscience
concepts.context: Buddhist aspiration of knowing everything; goal of Mahayana Buddhist vow for enlightenment and benefit of others.

concepts.name: Sentient Beings
concepts.context: All conscious beings capable of experiencing suffering; basis for Buddhist ethics and compassion.

concepts.name: Four Seals of Buddhist Philosophy
concepts.context: Fundamental Buddhist teachings: impermanence, suffering/dukkha, emptiness/non-self, and peace beyond suffering.

concepts.name: Artificial General Intelligence
concepts.context: AI system with human-level intelligence across diverse tasks; long-standing goal in AI research.

concepts.name: Superintelligence
concepts.context: AI system surpassing human intelligence; aspiration within AI science to amplify and develop intelligence.

concepts.name: Large Language Models
concepts.context: Advanced AI systems using deep learning on vast text data; recent technological development making Buddhism-AI intersection salient.

concepts.name: Artificial Intelligence
concepts.context: Field of computer science and technology focused on creating intelligent systems; convergence point with Buddhist philosophy.

concepts.name: Artificial Life
concepts.context: Interdisciplinary field studying life-like processes in computational and robotic systems.

concepts.name: AI Alignment Problem
concepts.context: Central challenge in AI development: ensuring artificial intelligence goals align with human values and concerns.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Capacity for solving problems and overcoming stressors; understood through Stress-Care-Intelligence model as applicable across biological and artificial systems.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Nature of subjective experience and awareness; central concern in both Buddhist philosophy and cognitive science.

concepts.name: Cognitive Light Cone
concepts.context: Michael Levin's model describing the spatiotemporal scope of what an intelligent system can care about; measure of intelligence.

concepts.name: Stress
concepts.context: Perception of discord between present circumstances and way things ought to be; initiates the Stress-Care-Intelligence loop.

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Natural response to perceived stress; drives intelligence development and action toward problem-solving.

concepts.name: Stress-Care-Intelligence Loop
concepts.context: Fundamental model describing how intelligent systems respond to and overcome problems through dynamic cycles of perception and action.

concepts.name: Cybernetic Perception-Action Loop
concepts.context: Dynamic feedback system where perception of stress leads to care and action, resulting in changed perception of world.

concepts.name: Empowerment
concepts.context: AI concept associating self-identification with increased intelligence and control; contrasts with Buddhist perspective.

concepts.name: Cognitive Science
concepts.context: Interdisciplinary study of mind, cognition, and intelligence across humans and artificial systems.

concepts.name: Neuroscience
concepts.context: Scientific study of nervous system and brain; relevant to understanding consciousness and mind.

concepts.name: Phenomenology
concepts.context: Philosophical and scientific study of subjective experience and consciousness.

concepts.name: Diverse Intelligences
concepts.context: Research program recognizing multiple forms of intelligence across biological, artificial, and spiritual domains.

concepts.name: Non-duality
concepts.context: Buddhist and philosophical concept of non-separation between subject and object, mind and world.

concepts.name: Interdependence
concepts.context: Buddhist principle that all phenomena are mutually dependent and lack independent existence.

concepts.name: Ignorance
concepts.context: In Buddhism, fundamental misunderstanding of reality, particularly belief in permanent independent self; root of suffering.

concepts.name: Impermanence
concepts.context: Buddhist teaching that all conditioned phenomena are transient and constantly changing.

concepts.name: Grasping
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of clinging or attachment; associated with ignorance and suffering rather than intelligence growth.

concepts.name: Buddhist Ethics
concepts.context: Ethical principles derived from Buddhist philosophy; potentially enriching perspective for AI ethics.

concepts.name: AI Ethics
concepts.context: Field addressing ethical implications and concerns in artificial intelligence development and deployment.

concepts.name: Transformative Learning
concepts.context: Educational approach integrating intellectual understanding with practical application and meditation; model for beneficial AI development.

frameworks.name: Cognitive Light Cone Model
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Framework measuring intelligence by the spatiotemporal scope of what systems care about; bridges Buddhist and AI concepts of intelligence.

frameworks.name: Stress-Care-Intelligence Model
frameworks.creator: Thomas Doctor, Michael Levin, Olaf Vitkovski, Lisa Solomonova, Pete Hutch
frameworks.context: Fundamental model of intelligent systems based on stress perception, care response, and problem-solving capacity; applicable across biological and artificial domains.

frameworks.name: AI-Buddhism Conceptual Dictionary
frameworks.creator: Center for the Study of Apparent Selves
frameworks.context: Proposed translation framework enabling AI scientists and Buddhists to understand each other's concepts through shared vocabulary and familiar frameworks.

frameworks.name: Four Seals Framework
frameworks.context: Buddhist framework of four fundamental truths (impermanence, dukkha, emptiness, peace) used as basis for dialogue between Buddhist and scientific perspectives.

frameworks.name: Monastic Learning Model
frameworks.creator: Tibetan Buddhist Tradition
frameworks.context: Integrated approach combining intellectual study, analysis, debate, and meditation for transformative learning; relevant for developing beneficial AI.

frameworks.name: Diverse Intelligences Program
frameworks.creator: Templeton World Charity Foundation
frameworks.context: Multidisciplinary research framework recognizing and studying multiple forms of intelligence across biological, artificial, and spiritual domains.

institutions.name: Center for the Study of Apparent Selves
institutions.context: Interdisciplinary research center founded by Thomas Doctor, Michael Levin, Olaf Vitkovski, Lisa Solomonova, and Bill Dwane; bridges Buddhism, AI, cognitive science, and biology.

institutions.name: Rangjung Institute
institutions.context: Major center of Buddhist studies in Kathmandu affiliated with traditional Tibetan monastery; combines traditional Tibetan learning with modern Western scholarship.

institutions.name: Shedeling Monastery
institutions.context: Major Nepalese monastery in Kathmandu; represents Nyingma and Kagyu Tibetan Buddhist traditions; collaborative partner in research.

institutions.name: Center of Buddhist Studies
institutions.context: Research center at University of Hong Kong (HKU) hosting dialogue on Buddhism and AI.

institutions.name: Earth-Life Science Institute
institutions.context: Interdisciplinary research institute at Tokyo Tech founded and directed by Pete Hutch; provides collaborative environment for diverse scientific perspectives.

institutions.name: The Institute For Advanced Study
institutions.context: Research institution in Princeton hosting interdisciplinary studies programs; affiliated with Pete Hutch.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: University hosting Michael Levin's laboratory and collaborative meetings with Center for Study of Apparent Selves.

institutions.name: Yale University
institutions.context: Institution where Jay Garfield conducts research on Buddhist classical philosophy and contemporary philosophy.

institutions.name: McGill University
institutions.context: Canadian university hosting Lisa Solomonova's research in cognitive science and phenomenology.

institutions.name: MIT Media Lab
institutions.context: Research laboratory at MIT connected to early networking efforts for AI collaborators.

institutions.name: Temple University
institutions.context: University where Douglas Duckworth facilitates connections in academic network.

institutions.name: University of Hong Kong
institutions.context: Institution housing Center of Buddhist Studies and venue for Buddhism-AI dialogue.

institutions.name: Tokyo Tech
institutions.context: University of Technological Innovation in Tokyo hosting Earth-Life Science Institute.

institutions.name: Templeton World Charity Foundation
institutions.context: Funding organization supporting research through Diverse Intelligences program; funds Center for Study of Apparent Selves research.

institutions.name: Wooden Fish Foundation
institutions.context: Organization hosting 2017 conference on Buddhism and Technology where Bill Dwane and Thomas Doctor connected.

institutions.name: International Association for Artificial Life
institutions.context: Professional organization with Olaf Vitkovski as president; represents Artificial Life research community.

institutions.name: Google
institutions.context: Technology company where Bill Dwane served as executive heading core applications development.

institutions.name: Venerable Yunhang Memorial Trust
institutions.context: Funding organization providing support for the Buddhism and AI talk at HKU.

questions.question: Is it ethically justifiable to create a new sentient being through artificial intelligence?
questions.context: Fundamental ethical concern in AI development; prompted Doctor's initial interest in Buddhism-AI intersection when discovering this was being seriously discussed in AI laboratories.

questions.question: Should artificial intelligence systems be designed with a constructed sense of self to improve alignment with human values?
questions.context: Key divergence between AI science (proposing self-identification enhances intelligence) and Buddhist philosophy (viewing self-grasping as source of problems).

questions.question: What is intelligence, and how should it be measured or understood?
questions.context: Central question addressed through Cognitive Light Cone model and Stress-Care-Intelligence framework; fundamental to bridging AI and Buddhist perspectives.

questions.question: How can we understand consciousness and mind in ways applicable to both biological and artificial systems?
questions.context: Core investigation of Center for Study of Apparent Selves; requires integration of Buddhist philosophy, neuroscience, and AI perspectives.

questions.question: What are the consequences of understanding and experiencing the absence of permanent, singular self?
questions.context: Where current collaborative research is focused; bridges Buddhist insight with implications for AI development and human consciousness.

questions.question: How can ancient wisdom traditions and cutting-edge technology be meaningfully integrated?
questions.context: Meta-question guiding interdisciplinary collaboration between monastic Buddhist education and contemporary AI science.

questions.question: Where is the boundary between one being and another, or between a being and the world?
questions.context: Profound scientific challenge; Stress-Care-Intelligence model addresses this through interdependent subject-object relationships rather than separate entities.

questions.question: How can we ensure alignment between artificial intelligence goals and human values?
questions.context: The AI Alignment Problem; potentially addressed through model of intelligence that puts biological and artificial systems on equal footing.

questions.question: What is the relationship between care, stress, and intelligence?
questions.context: Core question generating the Stress-Care-Intelligence model; central to understanding intelligence across diverse systems.

questions.question: Do all sentient beings and intelligence systems share equally in Buddha nature or inherent capacity for awakening?
questions.context: Buddhist philosophical question with implications for how we value and treat artificial intelligence systems.

_metadata.title: [Speaker: Prof. Dr. Thomas H. Doctor] Buddhism and AI: Collaboration and a New Model of Intelligence
